program.name: Senior Strength & Balance Foundation
program.description: A gentle 4-week program designed to build bone density, improve balance, and maintain independence through progressive strength training and stability work.

phases.name: Foundation Building Phase
phases.focus: Establish movement patterns, build bone density, and improve balance with safe, joint-friendly exercises.
phases.explanation: Phase 1 focuses on establish movement patterns, build bone density, and improve balance with safe, joint-friendly exercises.. Full Body split optimizes recovery between sessions.
phases.expectations: Focus on learning proper form and building habits. Some muscle soreness is normal.
keyPoints: Consistency is more important than perfection
Track your weights and reps to ensure progression
Get 7-9 hours of sleep for optimal recovery

exercises.name: Chair Squat
instructions: To begin, first set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Once the bar is loaded, step under it and position it across the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with your hands facing forward, unlock it and lift it off the rack by extending your legs.

Move your feet forward about 18 inches in front of the bar. Position your legs using a shoulder width stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Look forward at all times and maintain a neutral or slightly arched spine. This will be your starting position.

exercises.name: Smith Machine Bent Over Row
instructions: Set the barbell attached to the smith machine to a height that is about 2 inches below your knees.
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up.

Now grasp the barbell using an overhand (pronated) grip and unlock it from the smith machine rack. Then let it hang directly in front of you as your arms hang extended perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

exercises.name: Machine Bench Press
instructions: Sit down on the Chest Press Machine and select the weight.
Step on the lever provided by the machine since it will help you to bring the handles forward so that you can grab the handles and fully extend the arms.

Grab the handles with a palms-down grip and lift your elbows so that your upper arms are parallel to the floor to the sides of your torso. Tip: Your forearms will be pointing forward since you are grabbing the handles. Once you bring the handles forward and extend the arms you will be at the starting position.

exercises.name: Balance Board
instructions: Place a balance board in front of you.
Stand up on it and try to balance yourself.
Hold the balance for as long as desired.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and your hands on your hips.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.

exercises.name: Leverage Deadlift
instructions: Load the pins to an appropriate weight. Position yourself directly between the handles. Grasp the bottom handles with a comfortable grip, and then lower your hips as you take a breath. Look forward with your head and keep your chest up. This will be your starting position.
Return the weight to the starting position.

exercises.name: Lying T-Bar Row
instructions: Load up the T-bar Row Machine with the desired weight and adjust the leg height so that your upper chest is at the top of the pad. Tip: In some machines all you can do is stand on the appropriate step that allows you to be at a height that has the upper chest at the top of the pad.
Lay face down on the pad and grab the handles. You can either use a palms down, palms up, or palms in position depending on what part of your back you want to emphasize.
Lift the bar off the rack and extend your arms in front of you. This will be your starting position.

exercises.name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row
instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing your torso), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward by bending at the waist; as you bend make sure to keep your back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side (as you breathe out), keeping the elbows close to the body (do not exert any force with the forearm other than holding the weights). On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.

exercises.name: Smith Machine Squat
instructions: To begin, first set the bar on the height that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side (palms facing forward), unlock it and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

exercises.name: Balance Board
instructions: Place a balance board in front of you.
Stand up on it and try to balance yourself.
Hold the balance for as long as desired.

exercises.name: Bench Dips
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back. With the bench perpendicular to your body, and while looking away from it, hold on to the bench on its edge with the hands fully extended, separated at shoulder width. The legs will be extended forward, bent at the waist and perpendicular to your torso. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

exercises.name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing each other), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side as you breathe out, squeezing your shoulder blades together. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.

exercises.name: Arnold Dumbbell Press
instructions: Sit on an exercise bench with back support and hold two dumbbells in front of you at about upper chest level with your palms facing your body and your elbows bent. Tip: Your arms should be next to your torso. The starting position should look like the contracted portion of a dumbbell curl.
Now to perform the movement, raise the dumbbells as you rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward.
Continue lifting the dumbbells until your arms are extended above you in straight arm position. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and your hands on your hips.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Mid Row
instructions: Begin by taking a medium to wide grip on a pull-up apparatus with your palms facing away from you. From a hanging position, tuck your knees to your chest, leaning back and getting your legs over your side of the pull-up apparatus. This will be your starting position.
Beginning with your arms straight, flex the elbows and retract the shoulder blades to raise your body up until your legs contact the pull-up apparatus.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

progressionProtocol: Focus on form and movement quality first
When all sets feel comfortable (RPE 6-7), add 1-2 reps
Once reaching top of rep range with good form, increase weight by 2.5-5 lbs
If form breaks down, reduce weight and rebuild

program.name: Active Aging Foundation Program
program.description: A comprehensive 4-week beginner program designed for mature women focusing on bone density maintenance, balance improvement, and functional independence through safe, progressive strength training and stability work.

phases.name: Foundation Building Phase
phases.focus: Movement quality, balance, and safe strength progression
phases.explanation: This phase establishes proper movement patterns while building foundational strength to support bone density and improve balance for daily activities with grandchildren.
phases.expectations: Improved confidence with movement, better balance, reduced joint stiffness, and increased energy for daily activities.
keyPoints: Focus on form and control over speed or heavy weight
Listen to your body - mild muscle fatigue is normal, joint pain is not
Consistency is more important than intensity
Build confidence with supported movements before progressing

activities: Gentle hip circles and knee lifts

exercises.name: Leg Press Machine
exercises.notes: Start with light weight focusing on controlled movement. Avoid full knee extension.
instructions: Sit with back firmly against pad
Place feet hip-width apart on platform
Lower slowly until knees reach 90 degrees
Press through heels to return to start

exercises.name: Chest Press Machine
exercises.notes: Excellent for bone density in spine and arms. Keep shoulder blades back.
instructions: Adjust seat so handles align with mid-chest
Grip handles with firm but comfortable grip

exercises.name: Seated Cable Row
exercises.notes: Helps counteract forward posture and strengthens back for better balance.
instructions: Sit tall with slight bend in knees
Pull handle to lower chest, squeezing shoulder blades

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance Hold
exercises.notes: Progress by closing eyes or removing hand support as able.
instructions: Stand near wall or chair for support
Lift one foot slightly off ground
Hold position while maintaining good posture

exercises.name: Glute Bridge
exercises.notes: Great for hip stability and protecting previous hip replacement.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet flat

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown Machine
exercises.notes: Strengthens back and improves posture. Keep chest up throughout movement.
instructions: Sit with thighs secured under pad
Grip bar slightly wider than shoulders
Squeeze shoulder blades together at bottom

exercises.name: Leg Curl Machine
alternatives: Standing hamstring curls with resistance band
exercises.notes: Important for knee stability and balance. Use controlled motion.
instructions: Lie face down with pad behind ankles

exercises.name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press (Seated)
exercises.notes: Start with very light weights (2-5 lbs). Excellent for bone density.
instructions: Sit with back support, feet flat on floor
Press straight up without arching back
Lower with control to starting position

exercises.name: Modified Plank on Knees
exercises.notes: Build core strength gradually. Focus on maintaining straight line from head to knees.
instructions: Keep straight line from head to knees

exercises.name: Calf Raises
exercises.notes: Hold wall or rail for balance if needed. Important for ankle stability.

exercises.name: TRX Assisted Squat
exercises.notes: TRX provides support while building leg strength and balance.
instructions: Hold TRX handles with arms extended
Lower into squat using TRX for support
Return to standing using legs and TRX assistance

exercises.name: Stability Ball Wall Squats
exercises.notes: Ball provides back support while challenging stability.
instructions: Place ball between lower back and wall
Lower into squat, rolling ball up back

exercises.name: Heel-to-Toe Walking
exercises.notes: Walk near wall for support. Excellent for balance and fall prevention.
instructions: Place heel of front foot directly in front of toes of back foot

exercises.name: Side-Stepping
exercises.notes: Improves lateral stability and hip strength.
instructions: Bring other foot to meet it
Continue stepping in same direction, then reverse

exercises.name: Seated Spinal Rotation
exercises.notes: Gentle movement to maintain spinal mobility.
instructions: Rotate torso slowly to one side
Return to center and repeat other direction

exercises.name: Sit-to-Stand
exercises.notes: Essential functional movement. Use arms for assistance if needed initially.
instructions: Sit in chair with feet flat on floor
Stand up without using hands if possible

exercises.name: Step-Ups (Low Step)
exercises.notes: Start with 4-6 inch step. Hold rail for balance if needed.
instructions: Step up by pushing through heel
Bring other foot to meet it

exercises.name: Resistance Band Chest Press
exercises.notes: Mimics pushing movements needed for daily activities.
instructions: Anchor band behind you at chest height

exercises.name: Standing Marching
exercises.notes: Great for hip flexor strength and balance. Hold support if needed.

exercises.name: Ankle Circles
exercises.notes: Maintains ankle mobility important for balance and walking.
instructions: Sit in chair with one foot off ground

mealTiming: Eat protein at every meal to support muscle maintenance
Include calcium-rich foods for bone health
nutrition.notes: Focus on nutrient-dense foods including lean proteins, colorful vegetables, whole grains, and calcium-rich dairy or alternatives. Consider vitamin D supplementation as discussed with your doctor.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Focus on learning proper form and movement patterns
Week 3: Increase repetitions by 2-3 if form remains good
Week 4: Add light resistance or increase time for balance exercises
Listen to your body - some muscle fatigue is normal, joint pain is not
Progress balance exercises by reducing support as confidence improves

program.name: Mt. Rainier Preparation Program
program.description: 8-week endurance-focused strength program designed for intermediate hikers preparing for high-altitude climbing with emphasis on functional movement patterns.

phases.name: Foundation Phase
phases.focus: Build base strength and movement quality while developing aerobic capacity.
phases.explanation: Phase 1 focuses on build base strength and movement quality while developing aerobic capacity.. Full Body split optimizes recovery between sessions.
phases.expectations: Focus on learning proper form and building habits. Some muscle soreness is normal.
keyPoints: Consistency is more important than perfection
Track your weights and reps to ensure progression
Get 7-9 hours of sleep for optimal recovery

exercises.name: Barbell Deadlift
instructions: Stand in front of a loaded barbell.

While keeping the back as straight as possible, bend your knees, bend forward and grasp the bar using a medium (shoulder width) overhand grip. This will be the starting position of the exercise. Tip: If it is difficult to hold on to the bar with this grip, alternate your grip or use wrist straps.

While holding the bar, start the lift by pushing with your legs while simultaneously getting your torso to the upright position as you breathe out. In the upright position, stick your chest out and contract the back by bringing the shoulder blades back. Think of how the soldiers in the military look when they are in standing in attention.

exercises.name: Front Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

exercises.name: Bent Over Barbell Row
instructions: Holding a barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

Now, while keeping the torso stationary, breathe out and lift the barbell to you. Keep the elbows close to the body and only use the forearms to hold the weight. At the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

exercises.name: Barbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit on a bench with back support in a squat rack. Position a barbell at a height that is just above your head. Grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing forward).

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip width, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the shoulders slowly as you inhale.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.

exercises.name: Hang Clean
instructions: Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand or hook grip, with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.
Begin by aggressively extending through the hips, knees and ankles, driving the weight upward. As you do so, shrug your shoulders towards your ears.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

exercises.name: Front Squat (Clean Grip)
instructions: To begin, first set the bar in a rack slightly below shoulder level. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids, pushing into the clavicles, and lightly touching the throat. Your hands should be in a clean grip, touching the bar only with your fingers to help keep it in position.

Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso. Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head and elbows up at all times. This will be your starting position.

Bend at the knees, sitting down between your legs. Continue down until your hamstrings are on your calves. Keep your knees aligned with your feet by consciously using your abductors to push your knees out as you squat.

exercises.name: Clean Pull
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand or hook grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight and elbows out. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended. Full extension should be violent and abrupt, and ensure that you do not prolong the extension for longer than necessary.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Hang Clean
instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower kettlebell to a hanging position between your legs while keeping the hamstrings loaded. Keep your head up at all times.

exercises.name: Freehand Jump Squat
instructions: Cross your arms over your chest.
With your head up and your back straight, position your feet at shoulder width.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, squat down as you inhale until your upper thighs are parallel, or lower, to the floor.

exercises.name: Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

exercises.name: Cable Deadlifts
instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. Stand directly in between the uprights.
To begin, squat down be flexing your hips and knees until you can reach the handles.
After grasping them, begin your ascent. Driving through your heels extend your hips and knees keeping your hands hanging at your side. Keep your head and chest up throughout the movement.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

exercises.name: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in one hand. Stand on one leg, on the same side that you hold the kettlebell.
Keeping that knee slightly bent, perform a stiff legged deadlift by bending at the hip, extending your free leg behind you for balance.
Continue lowering the kettlebell until you are parallel to the ground, and then return to the upright position.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Squat style)
instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.
Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position.

Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to your feet. While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.

exercises.name: Deficit Deadlift
instructions: Begin by having a platform or weight plates that you can stand on, usually 1-3 inches in height. Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

exercises.name: One Leg Barbell Squat
instructions: Start by standing about 2 to 3 feet in front of a flat bench with your back facing the bench. Have a barbell in front of you on the floor. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Bend the knees and use a pronated grip with your hands being wider than shoulder width apart from each other to lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Then lift the barbell over your head and rest it on the base of your neck. Move one foot back so that your toe is resting on the flat bench. Your other foot should be stationary in front of you. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. Tip: Make sure your back is straight and chest is out while performing this exercise.

exercises.name: Clean and Press
instructions: Assume a shoulder-width stance, with knees inside the arms. Now while keeping the back flat, bend at the knees and hips so that you can grab the bar with the arms fully extended and a pronated grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Point the elbows out to sides. The bar should be close to the shins. Position the shoulders over or slightly ahead of the bar. Establish a flat back posture. This will be your starting position.

Begin to pull the bar by extending the knees. Move your hips forward and raise the shoulders at the same rate while keeping the angle of the back constant; continue to lift the bar straight up while keeping it close to your body.

As the bar passes the knee, extend at the ankles, knees, and hips forcefully, similar to a jumping motion. As you do so, continue to guide the bar with your hands, shrugging your shoulders and using the momentum from your movement to pull the bar as high as possible. The bar should travel close to your body, and you should keep your elbows out.

exercises.name: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.

Looking straight ahead at all times, squat as low as you can and pause at the bottom. As you squat down, push your knees out. You should squat between your legs, keeping an upright torso, with your head and chest up.
Rise back up by driving through your heels and repeat.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
instructions: Pick up a kettlebell with two hands and hold it by the horns. Hold one leg off of the floor and squat down on the other.
Squat down by flexing the knee and sitting back with the hips, holding the kettlebell up in front of you.
Hold the bottom position for a second and then reverse the motion, driving through the heel and keeping your head and chest up.

exercises.name: Alternating Hang Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell in a hanging position. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so.
Lower the cleaned kettlebell to a hanging position and clean the alternate kettlebell. Repeat.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Establish working weights at RPE 7
Week 3-4: Push to RPE 8, add weight when completing all reps
Add 5-10 lbs to lower body, 2.5-5 lbs to upper body when ready
Deload every 4-6 weeks: reduce volume by 40-50%

phases.name: Peak Endurance Phase
phases.focus: Maximize hiking-specific endurance and strength endurance for high-altitude performance.
phases.explanation: Phase 2 focuses on maximize hiking-specific endurance and strength endurance for high-altitude performance.. Full Body split optimizes recovery between sessions.
phases.expectations: You should feel stronger and more confident. Progressive overload becomes the focus.
keyPoints: Consistency is more important than perfection
Track your weights and reps to ensure progression
Get 7-9 hours of sleep for optimal recovery

exercises.name: Barbell Deadlift
instructions: Stand in front of a loaded barbell.

While keeping the back as straight as possible, bend your knees, bend forward and grasp the bar using a medium (shoulder width) overhand grip. This will be the starting position of the exercise. Tip: If it is difficult to hold on to the bar with this grip, alternate your grip or use wrist straps.

While holding the bar, start the lift by pushing with your legs while simultaneously getting your torso to the upright position as you breathe out. In the upright position, stick your chest out and contract the back by bringing the shoulder blades back. Think of how the soldiers in the military look when they are in standing in attention.

exercises.name: Front Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

exercises.name: Bent Over Barbell Row
instructions: Holding a barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

Now, while keeping the torso stationary, breathe out and lift the barbell to you. Keep the elbows close to the body and only use the forearms to hold the weight. At the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Push Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders.
Squat down a few inches and reverse the motion rapidly. Use the momentum from the legs to drive the kettlebells overhead.
Once the kettlebells are locked out, lower the kettlebells to your shoulders and repeat.

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Dead Clean
instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower the kettlebell, keeping the hamstrings loaded by keeping your back straight and your butt out.

exercises.name: Hang Clean
instructions: Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand or hook grip, with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.
Begin by aggressively extending through the hips, knees and ankles, driving the weight upward. As you do so, shrug your shoulders towards your ears.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

exercises.name: Kneeling Jump Squat
instructions: Begin kneeling on the floor with a barbell racked across the back of your shoulders, or you can use your body weight for this exercise. This can be done inside of a power rack to make unracking easier.
Sit back with your hips until your glutes touch your feet, keeping your head and chest up.
Explode up with your hips, generating enough power to land with your feet flat on the floor.

exercises.name: Clean and Jerk
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand or hook grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.

exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Snatch
instructions: Place two kettlebells behind your feet. Bend your knees and sit back to pick up the kettlebells.
Swing the kettlebells between your legs forcefully and reverse the direction.
Drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.

exercises.name: Freehand Jump Squat
instructions: Cross your arms over your chest.
With your head up and your back straight, position your feet at shoulder width.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, squat down as you inhale until your upper thighs are parallel, or lower, to the floor.

exercises.name: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
instructions: Initiate the exercise by standing upright with a kettlebell in one hand.
Swing the kettlebell back forcefully and then reverse the motion forcefully. Crush the kettlebell handle as hard as possible and raise the kettlebell to your shoulder.

exercises.name: Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

exercises.name: Cable Deadlifts
instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. Stand directly in between the uprights.
To begin, squat down be flexing your hips and knees until you can reach the handles.
After grasping them, begin your ascent. Driving through your heels extend your hips and knees keeping your hands hanging at your side. Keep your head and chest up throughout the movement.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

exercises.name: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in one hand. Stand on one leg, on the same side that you hold the kettlebell.
Keeping that knee slightly bent, perform a stiff legged deadlift by bending at the hip, extending your free leg behind you for balance.
Continue lowering the kettlebell until you are parallel to the ground, and then return to the upright position.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Squat style)
instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.
Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position.

Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to your feet. While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.

exercises.name: Deficit Deadlift
instructions: Begin by having a platform or weight plates that you can stand on, usually 1-3 inches in height. Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

exercises.name: One Leg Barbell Squat
instructions: Start by standing about 2 to 3 feet in front of a flat bench with your back facing the bench. Have a barbell in front of you on the floor. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Bend the knees and use a pronated grip with your hands being wider than shoulder width apart from each other to lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Then lift the barbell over your head and rest it on the base of your neck. Move one foot back so that your toe is resting on the flat bench. Your other foot should be stationary in front of you. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. Tip: Make sure your back is straight and chest is out while performing this exercise.

exercises.name: Clean and Press
instructions: Assume a shoulder-width stance, with knees inside the arms. Now while keeping the back flat, bend at the knees and hips so that you can grab the bar with the arms fully extended and a pronated grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Point the elbows out to sides. The bar should be close to the shins. Position the shoulders over or slightly ahead of the bar. Establish a flat back posture. This will be your starting position.

Begin to pull the bar by extending the knees. Move your hips forward and raise the shoulders at the same rate while keeping the angle of the back constant; continue to lift the bar straight up while keeping it close to your body.

As the bar passes the knee, extend at the ankles, knees, and hips forcefully, similar to a jumping motion. As you do so, continue to guide the bar with your hands, shrugging your shoulders and using the momentum from your movement to pull the bar as high as possible. The bar should travel close to your body, and you should keep your elbows out.

exercises.name: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.

Looking straight ahead at all times, squat as low as you can and pause at the bottom. As you squat down, push your knees out. You should squat between your legs, keeping an upright torso, with your head and chest up.
Rise back up by driving through your heels and repeat.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
instructions: Pick up a kettlebell with two hands and hold it by the horns. Hold one leg off of the floor and squat down on the other.
Squat down by flexing the knee and sitting back with the hips, holding the kettlebell up in front of you.
Hold the bottom position for a second and then reverse the motion, driving through the heel and keeping your head and chest up.

exercises.name: Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell.
With a fluid motion, lower the top kettlebell while driving the bottom kettlebell up.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Establish working weights at RPE 7
Week 3-4: Push to RPE 8, add weight when completing all reps
Add 5-10 lbs to lower body, 2.5-5 lbs to upper body when ready
Deload every 4-6 weeks: reduce volume by 40-50%

program.name: Mt. Rainier Mountaineering Preparation Program
program.description: 8-week specialized training program designed for Mt. Rainier climb preparation, focusing on building hiking endurance, functional strength, and altitude adaptation while accommodating frequent travel with hotel gym alternatives

phases.name: Base Building Phase
phases.focus: Establish aerobic base, build functional strength foundation, and develop movement patterns essential for mountaineering
phases.explanation: This phase develops the cardiovascular and muscular endurance foundation necessary for long alpine ascents while strengthening key muscle groups used in mountaineering activities
phases.expectations: Improved general endurance, better movement quality, increased strength in hiking-specific patterns, and adaptation to training volume
keyPoints: Focus on time under tension and muscular endurance
Build aerobic capacity with moderate intensity cardio
Master fundamental movement patterns
Establish consistent training rhythm despite travel

workouts.name: Endurance Foundation
workouts.focus: Cardiovascular base building with lower body strength emphasis

exercises.name: Stair Climber
exercises.notes: Maintain steady pace, simulate hiking rhythm

exercises.name: Goblet Squat
instructions: Squat to hip crease below knee

exercises.name: Walking Lunges
instructions: Push off front foot to next step

exercises.name: Single-leg Romanian Deadlift
exercises.notes: Improves balance and posterior chain strength
instructions: Hinge at hip while lifting leg back
Maintain straight line from head to heel

exercises.name: Step-ups
instructions: Step up with full foot contact

workouts.name: Functional Strength
workouts.focus: Upper body and core strength with mountaineering movement patterns

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown
exercises.notes: Essential for rope work and scrambling

exercises.name: Overhead Press
exercises.notes: Important for pack lifting and overhead reach

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.notes: Core stability for heavy pack carrying
instructions: Straight line from head to heels

exercises.name: Dead Bug
instructions: Lie on back, arms and legs at 90
Maintain lower back contact with floor

workouts.name: Endurance Plus
workouts.focus: Extended cardiovascular training with weighted vest introduction

exercises.name: Treadmill Hiking Simulation
exercises.notes: Start with 10-15 lbs in vest, progress weekly
instructions: Use trekking pole motion with arms

exercises.name: Bulgarian Split Squat
exercises.notes: Unilateral leg strength crucial for uneven terrain

exercises.name: Wall Sit
exercises.notes: Isometric leg strength for long descents

workouts.name: Recovery & Mobility
workouts.focus: Active recovery with mobility work and light strength maintenance

exercises.name: Light Cardio Choice
exercises.notes: Focus on movement quality, not intensity

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squats
instructions: Focus on full range of motion

exercises.name: Hip Flexor Stretch
instructions: Feel stretch in front of hip

exercises.name: Cat-Cow Stretch
instructions: Alternate between arched and rounded back

mealTiming: Pre-workout: Light carb snack 30-60 min before
nutrition.notes: Focus on whole foods, adequate hydration (half body weight in oz), and foods you'll eat on the mountain. Practice fueling strategies during longer sessions.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Focus on form and establishing routine
Week 3: Increase cardio duration by 5 minutes
Week 4: Add 5-10 lbs to weighted vest, increase strength exercise reps by 2-3

phases.name: Mountaineering Specific Phase
phases.focus: Advanced endurance building, altitude simulation, technical strength, and mountain-specific movement patterns
phases.explanation: This phase intensifies training to simulate actual mountain conditions, builds advanced cardiovascular capacity, and develops the specific strength and endurance patterns required for Mt. Rainier
phases.expectations: Significant improvement in hiking endurance, ability to handle sustained elevation gain, increased strength under fatigue, and confidence in mountain-specific movements
keyPoints: Longer duration endurance sessions with weight
Higher intensity interval training for altitude adaptation
Advanced unilateral and functional strength patterns
Mental preparation for sustained effort

workouts.name: Alpine Endurance
workouts.focus: Extended duration training with weighted vest progression

exercises.name: Weighted Vest Hiking Simulation
exercises.notes: Progress to 20-30 lbs. Include 2-3 brief rest stops

exercises.name: Step-ups with Knee Drive
exercises.notes: Focus on explosive drive and balance

exercises.name: Lateral Lunges
exercises.notes: Essential for traversing and unstable terrain

exercises.name: Single-leg Glute Bridge
instructions: Lie on back, one foot planted
Lift hips up using planted leg

exercises.name: Calf Raise to Toe Walk
exercises.notes: Ankle strength and stability for rocky terrain
instructions: Stay on toes and walk 10 steps

workouts.name: Power & Technical Strength
workouts.focus: Explosive power development and technical climbing strength

exercises.name: Russian Twists
exercises.notes: Rotational core strength for pack stability

workouts.name: Endurance Challenge
workouts.focus: Extended endurance with mountain simulation and mental preparation

exercises.name: Long Weighted Hike Simulation
exercises.notes: Build to pack weight. Include nutrition practice

workouts.name: Technical Skills & Recovery
workouts.focus: Movement skills, balance, and active recovery with mobility emphasis

exercises.name: Balance and Agility Circuit
exercises.notes: Combine single-leg stands, heel-to-toe walking, direction changes

mealTiming: Pre-workout: Complex carbs 60-90 min before longer sessions
During workout: Sports drink or energy gels for sessions over 45 min
Post-workout: 3:1 carb to protein ratio within 30 min
Practice mountain nutrition during weekend sessions
nutrition.notes: Increase total calories to support higher training volume. Practice eating foods you'll use on the mountain. Focus on easy-to-digest options during training. Hydration becomes critical - aim for pale yellow urine.

progressionProtocol: Week 5: Increase weighted vest to 20-25 lbs for applicable exercises
Week 6: Extend main cardio sessions by 10 minutes, add 5 lbs to strength exercises
Week 7: Peak intensity - longest durations and heaviest loads
Week 8: Begin taper - maintain intensity but reduce volume by 20%

program.name: Postpartum Core Recovery Program
program.description: 8-week progressive program designed to rebuild core strength and regain pre-pregnancy fitness with diastasis recti considerations.

phases.name: Foundation Phase
phases.focus: Establish movement patterns and gradual strength building with core-safe exercises.
phases.explanation: Phase 1 focuses on establish movement patterns and gradual strength building with core-safe exercises.. Full Body split optimizes recovery between sessions.
phases.expectations: Focus on learning proper form and building habits. Some muscle soreness is normal.
keyPoints: Consistency is more important than perfection
Track your weights and reps to ensure progression
Get 7-9 hours of sleep for optimal recovery

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.

exercises.name: Alternating Kettlebell Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Press one directly overhead by extending through the elbow, turning it so the palm faces forward while holding the other kettlebell stationary .
Lower the pressed kettlebell to the starting position and immediately press with your other arm.

exercises.name: Bench Dips
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back. With the bench perpendicular to your body, and while looking away from it, hold on to the bench on its edge with the hands fully extended, separated at shoulder width. The legs will be extended forward, bent at the waist and perpendicular to your torso. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

exercises.name: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift
instructions: Grasp a couple of dumbbells holding them by your side at arm's length.
Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the dumbbells to over the top of your feet by bending at the waist while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Exhale as you perform this movement

exercises.name: Alternating Renegade Row
instructions: Place two kettlebells on the floor about shoulder width apart. Position yourself on your toes and your hands as though you were doing a pushup, with the body straight and extended. Use the handles of the kettlebells to support your upper body. You may need to position your feet wide for support.
Push one kettlebell into the floor and row the other kettlebell, retracting the shoulder blade of the working side as you flex the elbow, pulling it to your side.
Then lower the kettlebell to the floor and begin the kettlebell in the opposite hand. Repeat for several reps.

exercises.name: Arnold Dumbbell Press
instructions: Sit on an exercise bench with back support and hold two dumbbells in front of you at about upper chest level with your palms facing your body and your elbows bent. Tip: Your arms should be next to your torso. The starting position should look like the contracted portion of a dumbbell curl.
Now to perform the movement, raise the dumbbells as you rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward.
Continue lifting the dumbbells until your arms are extended above you in straight arm position. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement.

exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. As you bend down to grab the kettlebell, push your butt back and keep your eyes looking forward.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Return the weight to the starting position.

exercises.name: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in one hand. Stand on one leg, on the same side that you hold the kettlebell.
Keeping that knee slightly bent, perform a stiff legged deadlift by bending at the hip, extending your free leg behind you for balance.
Continue lowering the kettlebell until you are parallel to the ground, and then return to the upright position.

exercises.name: Alternating Floor Press
instructions: Lie on the floor with two kettlebells next to your shoulders.
Position one in place on your chest and then the other, gripping the kettlebells on the handle with the palms facing forward.
Extend both arms, so that the kettlebells are being held above your chest. Lower one kettlebell, bringing it to your chest and turn the wrist in the direction of the locked out kettlebell.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Establish working weights at RPE 7
Week 3-4: Push to RPE 8, add weight when completing all reps
Add 5-10 lbs to lower body, 2.5-5 lbs to upper body when ready
Deload every 4-6 weeks: reduce volume by 40-50%

phases.name: Strength Phase
phases.focus: Progressive strength building with increased intensity and complexity.
phases.explanation: Phase 2 focuses on progressive strength building with increased intensity and complexity.. Full Body split optimizes recovery between sessions.
phases.expectations: You should feel stronger and more confident. Progressive overload becomes the focus.
keyPoints: Consistency is more important than perfection
Track your weights and reps to ensure progression
Get 7-9 hours of sleep for optimal recovery

exercises.name: Kettlebell Hang Clean
instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower kettlebell to a hanging position between your legs while keeping the hamstrings loaded. Keep your head up at all times.

exercises.name: Trap Bar Deadlift
instructions: For this exercise load a trap bar, also known as a hex bar, to an appropriate weight resting on the ground. Stand in the center of the apparatus and grasp both handles.
Lower your hips, look forward with your head and keep your chest up.
Begin the movement by driving through the heels and extend your hips and knees. Avoid rounding your back at all times.

exercises.name: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.

Looking straight ahead at all times, squat as low as you can and pause at the bottom. As you squat down, push your knees out. You should squat between your legs, keeping an upright torso, with your head and chest up.
Rise back up by driving through your heels and repeat.

exercises.name: Bent Over Barbell Row
instructions: Holding a barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

Now, while keeping the torso stationary, breathe out and lift the barbell to you. Keep the elbows close to the body and only use the forearms to hold the weight. At the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

exercises.name: One-Arm Kettlebell Snatch
instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. Bend your knees and push your butt back to get in the proper starting position.
Look straight ahead and swing the kettlebell back between your legs.

Immediately reverse the direction and drive through with your hips and knees, accelerating the kettlebell upward. As the kettlebell rises to your shoulder rotate your hand and punch straight up, using momentum to receive the weight locked out overhead.

exercises.name: Battling Ropes
instructions: For this exercise you will need a heavy rope anchored at its center 15-20 feet away. Standing in front of the rope, take an end in each hand with your arms extended at your side. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rapidly raising one arm to shoulder level as quickly as you can.
As you let that arm drop to the starting position, raise the opposite side.

exercises.name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Squat style)
instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.
Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position.

Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to your feet. While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.

exercises.name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.

exercises.name: Air Bike
instructions: Lie flat on the floor with your lower back pressed to the ground. For this exercise, you will need to put your hands beside your head. Be careful however to not strain with the neck as you perform it. Now lift your shoulders into the crunch position.
Bring knees up to where they are perpendicular to the floor, with your lower legs parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

Now simultaneously, slowly go through a cycle pedal motion kicking forward with the right leg and bringing in the knee of the left leg. Bring your right elbow close to your left knee by crunching to the side, as you breathe out.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Establish working weights at RPE 7
Week 3-4: Push to RPE 8, add weight when completing all reps
Add 5-10 lbs to lower body, 2.5-5 lbs to upper body when ready
Deload every 4-6 weeks: reduce volume by 40-50%

program.name: Postpartum Core Recovery & Strength Rebuild Program
program.description: 8-week progressive program designed for postpartum recovery, focusing on diastasis recti healing, core stabilization, and gradual return to strength training with safe progressions.

phases.name: Foundation & Core Recovery
phases.focus: Diastasis recti healing, movement quality, and building base strength
phases.explanation: This phase prioritizes core rehabilitation with DR-safe exercises, establishes movement patterns, and gradually builds strength foundation while respecting postpartum body changes.
phases.expectations: Improved core stability, better posture, reduced back pain, increased energy levels, and measurable improvement in diastasis recti gap.
keyPoints: Focus on diaphragmatic breathing and pelvic floor coordination
Avoid traditional crunches and front-loading exercises
Emphasize functional movement patterns
Monitor diastasis recti weekly for improvement

workouts.name: Foundation A
workouts.focus: Core stability and upper body strength

exercises.name: Glute Bridge
exercises.notes: Focus on pelvic floor engagement at the top

exercises.name: Wall Push-up
exercises.notes: Maintain straight line from head to feet

exercises.name: Modified Bird Dog
exercises.notes: Start with just arm or leg, progress to opposite limbs

exercises.name: Side-lying Leg Lift
exercises.notes: Keep hips stacked, slow controlled movement

exercises.name: Dead Bug
exercises.notes: Key exercise for diastasis recti - lower back stays flat
instructions: Lie on back, arms up, knees bent 90
Lower opposite arm and leg slowly

workouts.name: Foundation B
workouts.focus: Lower body strength and posterior chain

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
exercises.notes: Focus on proper depth and form
instructions: Lower as if sitting in chair
Keep chest up, knees track over toes

exercises.name: Stationary Lunge
exercises.notes: Use wall for balance if needed
instructions: Push through front heel to return

exercises.name: Modified Plank
exercises.notes: Start on knees, progress to full plank as able
instructions: Keep straight line from head to knees

exercises.name: Pallof Press with Band
exercises.notes: Excellent for diastasis recti - resist rotation
instructions: Hold with both hands at chest

exercises.name: Assisted Pull-up/Negative
exercises.notes: Use band assistance or focus on slow negatives
instructions: Use band for assistance or jump to top

exercises.name: Dumbbell Deadlift (Light)
exercises.notes: Start with 10-15 lbs, focus on hip hinge pattern

exercises.name: Standing Band Row
exercises.notes: Attach band to sturdy anchor point

exercises.name: Farmer's Carry (Short)
exercises.notes: Use 10-15 lb dumbbells, focus on posture

exercises.name: Heel Slides
exercises.notes: Gentle core activation, good for diastasis recti

mealTiming: Pre-workout snack if exercising >2 hours after meal
nutrition.notes: Focus on nutrient-dense foods to support recovery. Stay well hydrated, especially if breastfeeding. Include calcium and iron-rich foods.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Focus on form mastery and movement quality
Week 3-4: Increase reps by 2-3 or time by 5-10 seconds
Monitor diastasis recti gap weekly - should begin to narrow
Progress from modified to full versions when able to maintain form

phases.name: Strength Building & Integration
phases.focus: Progressive strength training with continued core rehabilitation
phases.explanation: Building on the foundation, this phase introduces moderate weights and more challenging exercises while maintaining diastasis recti-safe protocols and progressing toward pre-pregnancy fitness levels.
phases.expectations: Noticeable strength gains, improved functional movement, further diastasis recti improvement, and increased confidence with exercise progression.
keyPoints: Gradual weight progression with dumbbells
Introduction of compound movements
Continued focus on core stability in all exercises
Begin incorporating pre-pregnancy favorite exercises safely

workouts.name: Strength A
workouts.focus: Upper body strength and core stability

exercises.name: Dumbbell Chest Press (Floor)
exercises.notes: Start with 10-15 lbs, lying on floor limits range
instructions: Pause briefly when triceps touch floor

exercises.name: Dumbbell Bent-over Row
exercises.notes: Keep core engaged, avoid rounding back

exercises.name: Plank to Downward Dog
exercises.notes: Dynamic core exercise, great for diastasis recti
instructions: Pike hips up to downward dog

exercises.name: Band Face Pull
instructions: Pull band to face, elbows high

workouts.name: Strength B
workouts.focus: Lower body power and functional movement

exercises.name: Goblet Squat
exercises.notes: Hold dumbbell at chest, promotes good form

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift
exercises.notes: Focus on hip hinge, hamstring stretch

exercises.name: Reverse Lunge with Dumbbells
exercises.notes: Easier on knees than forward lunge
instructions: Push through front heel to return

exercises.name: Single-leg Glute Bridge
instructions: Lie on back, one foot flat

exercises.name: Copenhagen Plank
exercises.notes: Advanced side plank variation for core
instructions: Side plank with top leg on couch/chair

exercises.name: Dumbbell Thruster
exercises.notes: Compound movement combining squat and press

exercises.name: Step-ups
instructions: Complete all reps one leg, then switch

exercises.name: Bear Crawl
exercises.notes: Excellent for core stability and coordination

mealTiming: Spread protein throughout day for muscle recovery
nutrition.notes: Increase calories slightly to support strength gains. Focus on anti-inflammatory foods to aid recovery. Consider adding creatine if approved by healthcare provider.

progressionProtocol: Week 1-2: Establish weights that allow good form for all reps
Week 3-4: Increase weight by 2.5-5 lbs when can complete all sets/reps easily
Progress pull-ups by reducing band assistance gradually
Add weight to bodyweight exercises when ready
